text:
I am a small-business owner, operating 4 Dunkin Donut franchises that employ 75 individuals in the state of New Hampshire. I am writing today to request that you amend the Final Rule titled "Food Labeling; Nutrition Labeling of Standard Menu Items in Restaurants and Similar Retail Food Establishment" ("Rule") issued on Dec. 1, 2014, to provide for more flexible options for restaurateurs across the country.

As currently written, the rule requires that caloric information be displayed on the menus and menu boards next to the name or price of the item. The calories must be posted in a type face that is the size of either the name or the price, whichever is smaller, and must be in the same color "or at least as conspicuous" as the name used for the item. Other information, including total calories, total fat, calories from fat, saturated fat, trans fat, cholesterol, sodium, total carbohydrates, fiber, sugars and protein, must be provided in written form upon consumer request and noted as such on menus and menu boards.

This rule creates a one-standard-fits-all model that does not take into consideration the unique nature of the foodservice industry, including the hundreds of combinations of food items that impact the nutritional data. It also does not allow for a business owner like me to cure even minor violations without facing criminal and civil penalties. With today's demand to always change our offerings and keep up with the always hanging day to day operations this can be quite difficult. Furthermore rule includes an exemption for operations with fewer than 20 locations, the exemption does not apply to franchisees like me who operate an independent business.

I ask that you reconsider the rule to allow for more flexible posting alternatives. For example, allowing employers to place information on one listing designated as the "menu" or "menu board" will lessen posting errors or a website to post new menu items that guests may access on their phone or other mobile device that it very common for an individual to carry. Additionally, allowing for flexibility in determining which serving sizes are appropriate to be used (single servings, entire product or common unit of division) will limit errors while providing identical information to the consumer. I also ask that you remove the requirement that each franchise location have an employee certify that every food item adheres to the nutrient values as determined by the corporate entity. As a small-business owner, I have neither the time nor the resources to ensure that these qualifications are met. Finally, inserting a 90-day "cure period" for those who act in good faith and are non-compliant due to inadvertent human error would allow small-business owners like me to focus on running my business and growing jobs rather than living in fear of a violation. Putting the burden on the employer with no chance to rectify a situation and act in good faith is very concerning.

Thank you for delaying implementation of this rule so that FDA and others can fully analyze its impact on small-business owners across the country. I appreciate you considering my suggestions and am happy to provide further input as requested.
docAbstract: Final Rule published 79 FR 71156 December 1, 2014 Rules and Regulations eff December 1, 2015

text:
I am writing to ask that you not postpone the compliance dates under the Effluent Limitation Guidelines and Standards for Steam Electric Power Plants ("ELG rule"). Postponing and rewriting this rule will delay long needed reductions in toxic pollution to drinking water sources for communities and waterways around the country.

Every year, over 2 billion pounds of toxic wastewater is dumped into our waterways by power plants - the largest source of toxic water pollution in our country. This wastewater contains heavy metals and chemicals known to harm human health, like lead, mercury and arsenic. Approximately 23,000 miles of rivers and streams in the United States are contaminated because of this pollution, including many drinking water sources. Many of these dangerous contaminants become more concentrated in animals as they move up the food chain, which means the impacts to the ecosystem go beyond just aquatic animals - they can hurt or kill any animals that eat the contaminated fish -- including humans.

Power plants should not get a free pass to poison our water, food sources and our children. And the public should not have to bear the costs when public drinking water requires expensive treatments because of their dumping. The technology to stop these pollutants from entering waterways is available and affordable. Many power plants are already implementing it.

I urge you to reconsider this action and allow the long-awaited and very necessary ELG rule to be fully implemented under the schedule set forth in the ELG Rule.
docAbstract: EPA announced on September 15, 2009 the start of a rulemaking process to revise the effluent limitations guidelines and standards for the steam electric power generating point source category (i.e., steam electric power plants).  EPA’s decision to proceed with a rulemaking was made upon reviewing the findings from a multi-year study of wastewater discharges from power plants.EPA’s review of wastewater discharges from power plants, and the treatment technologies available to reduce pollutant discharges, has demonstrated the need to update the current national effluent guidelines regulations.  The current regulations, which were last updated in 1982, do not adequately address the pollutants being discharged and have not kept pace with changes that have occurred in the electric power industry over the last three decades.

I am urging the Department to grant relief to the tens of thousands of students who are still waiting for their loans to be cancelled, even though the Department itself found that their school (Corinthian) broke the law.

The Department must stop giving federal loans and grants to schools that do not equip their graduates to succeed in their careers. Taxpayer-backed loan money shouldn't be used to turn for-profit college executives into millionaires, even as they scam students.

It is a total waste of taxpayer money to re-do rules that were thoroughly debated during the Obama Administration. The borrower defense and gainful employment rules work to ensure that taxpayers aren't subsidizing schools that bury their students in debt for a useless degree, and should be enforced, not delayed and dismantled.

I respectfully request the Department to act fairly on the part of students whose loans have yet to be cancelled, even though Corinthian university was determined to have broken the law. To not forgive those loans is to damage those students' ability to live full and productive lives as Americans.

I am greatly concerned by the Department's support of universities that do not actually give students a chance to succeed, and are built on for-profit platforms. These schools go against the spirit of education in this country, a country that was built on the idea that anyone can work hard enough to achieve their dreams. By scamming their students they are profiting off the hopes and dreams and hard work of Americans who deserve better.

The borrower defense and gainful employment rules ensure that taxpayers aren't subsidizing schools that bury their students in debt for a useless degree, and should be enforced. Please don't waste time debating these rules and enforce the protections of hard-working Americans. Thank you.

I think that the EPA should NOT postpone compliance dates for effluent emissions. Power companies have had two years to bring their plants into compliance with these new updated standards. Furthermore, this is only the latest in a broad effluent reduction that began with the Clean Water Act, and should continue if the water coming out of an industrial plant is as clean or cleaner than the water going in. This should come as no surprise, so why the power companies should be asking for a stay is, to my mind, infantile whining of people who do not wish to spend the necessary time and energy and money to enforce the globally necessary outcome. Once again, do NOT grant a stay on the compliance date. Put it into effect as planned.
